Is your Apple device asking unexpectedly to approve a password change? In short, you probably don't need to worry if you've enabled 2FA. If you haven't enabled two-factor authentication on your Apple ID, you should do that. Here's my take, but perhaps others can share theirs. üßµ

If you have physical access to these devices and can unlock them, you'll be able to select a new Apple ID password. In this scenario, the remote attacker cannot reset your password even if they were able to initiate the change request. https://t.co/0LWXsjidzx

I'm uncertain why attackers are initiating such requests. Maybe they're looking for Apple IDs without 2FA that reuse passwords that attackers harvested in some data breach? A similar campaign was discussed in this article by @realkrauswife two years ago: https://t.co/ucEnRgdp3X

If you enabled two-factor authentication on your Apple ID account, this will cause Apple to pop up a note on your Apple devices and possibly send you a text message, allowing you to use your devices to reset the password. https://t.co/e0kqzSIbDD
